snippet: The group released a video showing the beheading of a second American, blaming President Obama for the death and raising the pressure on him to order strikes on the group in Syria.
lead_paragraph: The group released a video showing the beheading of a second American, blaming President Obama for the death and raising the pressure on him to order strikes on the group in Syria.
abstract: Video released by ISIS shows the beheading of freelance journalist Steven J Sotloff, second American hostage to be slain in two weeks; militants put blame for his brutal murder on Pres Obama; killing raises pressure on president to order strike on group's sanctuary in Syria; video has not yet been authenticated, but most sources believe he is dead.

snippet: A Syrian group led by a former member of Osama bin Laden’s inner circle is seen as more dangerous than the Islamic State for its potential to launch terror attacks.
lead_paragraph: A Syrian group led by a former member of Osama bin Laden’s inner circle is seen as more dangerous than the Islamic State for its potential to launch terror attacks.
abstract: Intelligence and law enforcement officials say Syrian group Khorasan poses more direct threat to America and Europe than Islamic State; Khorasan, led by former senior Qaeda operative Muhsin al-Fadhli, has emerged in past year as cell in Syria that may be most intent on hitting United States or its installations overseas with terror attack.

snippet: Britain, Belgium and Denmark lined up behind the United States, agreeing to military operations in Iraq — but not in Syria.
lead_paragraph: Britain, Belgium and Denmark lined up behind the United States, agreeing to military operations in Iraq — but not in Syria.
abstract: Great Britain, Belgium and Denmark join United States in its fight against Islamic State group, agreeing to military operations in Iraq, but refuse for now to take direct intervention in Syria; entry of British into coalition provides Washington with broader consensus for what is described as extended campaign waged without a resolution authorizing use of military force by United Nations Security Council.

lead_paragraph: No one is advocating an invasion, but we need a military strategy, and a far greater sense of urgency.
abstract: Op-Ed article by Sens John McCain and Lindsey Graham calls on Pres Obama to confront the Islamic State of Iraq and Syria with direct military action; warns ISIS poses a growing threat to America and that containment is not a valid option; outlines broad strategy and calls on war-weary Americans to be supportive should Obama choose to take up arms.

lead_paragraph: There’s inadequate urgency or reassurance in the president’s language, as Americans gaze with horror at events abroad.
abstract: Frank Bruni Op-Ed column criticizes way Pres Obama has publicly addressed problem of Islamic State in Iraq and Syria militants, saying there is 'no strategy yet' for dealing with them; questions why he has offered little reassurance to the American public, and also why he seems to lack a sense of urgency about the cosmically dire state of global events.

lead_paragraph: American officials have made it clear they do not want the airstrikes to get ahead of the ground action against ISIS, which they said would take time to mass.
abstract: Obama administration says several Arab nations have offered to join in airstrikes against Islamic State in Iraq and Syria; officials say any sustained military campaign does not appear imminent and is likely to require even more significant commitment from other nations and fighting forces in region.

snippet: Intelligence agents are laying the groundwork for what they hope will become an effective force of rebel ground troops in the battle against the Islamic State.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence agents are laying the groundwork for what they hope will become an effective force of rebel ground troops in the battle against the Islamic State.
abstract: Intelligence agents from United States and its allies are laying the groundwork for what they hope will become an effective force of Syrian rebels to serve as ground troops in international battle against the Islamic State; rebels themselves acknowledge that turning relatively small group into force that can challenge well-funded and well-armed Islamic State is challenge that will require huge support from its foreign backers.

snippet: As lawmakers around the world debate laws intended to stop citizens from fighting for foreign terrorist groups, the U.S. is seeking a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
lead_paragraph: As lawmakers around the world debate laws intended to stop citizens from fighting for foreign terrorist groups, the U.S. is seeking a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
abstract: Rapid surge of Islamic State in Iraq and Syria, and its ability to draw fighters from across the globe, have set off alarm bells in capitals worldwide; countries that rarely see eye to eye are now trying to blunt its recruitment drive, passing a raft of new rules that they hope will stop their citizens from joining extremist groups abroad; United States is pushing for a legally binding United Nations Security Council resolution.
